ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle:
Spectroscopic properties of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped K–Sr–Al phosphate glasses

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Trivalent holmium-doped K–Sr–Al phosphate glasses (
P 2
O 5
$\mathrm{P}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}$ –
K 2
O
$\mathrm{K}_{2}\mathrm{O}$ –SrO–
Al 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Al}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ –
Ho 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Ho}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ ) were prepared, and their spectroscopic properties have been evaluated using absorption, emission, and excitation measurements. The Judd–Ofelt theory has been used to derive spectral intensities of various absorption bands from measured absorption spectrum of 1.0 mol%
Ho 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Ho}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ -doped K–Sr–Al phosphate glass. The Judd–Ofelt intensity parameters (
Ω λ
$\varOmega_{\lambda}$ ,
×
10
− 20
cm 2
$\times10^{-20}~\mathrm{cm}^{2}$ ) have been determined of the order of
Ω 2
= 11.39
$\varOmega_{2} = 11.39$ ,
Ω 4
= 3.59
$\varOmega_{4} = 3.59$ , and
Ω 6
= 2.92
$\varOmega_{6} = 2.92$ , which in turn used to derive radiative properties such as radiative transition probability, radiative lifetime, branching ratios, etc. for excited states of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions. The radiative lifetimes for the
F 4
5
${}^{5}F_{4}$ ,
S 2
5
${}^{5}S_{2}$ , and
F 5
5
${}^{5}F_{5}$ levels of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions are found to be 169, 296, and 317 μs, respectively. The stimulated emission cross-section for 2.05-μm emission was calculated by the McCumber theory and found to be
9.3 ×
10
− 2 1
cm 2
$9.3\times10^{-2 1}~\mathrm{cm}^{2}$ . The wavelength-dependent gain coefficient with population inversion rate has been evaluated. The results obtained in the titled glasses are discussed systematically and compared with other
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped systems to assess the possibility for visible and infrared device applications.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Investigations on trivalent rare-earth (
RE
3 +
$\mathrm{RE}^{3+}$ )-doped glasses have attracted considerable attention due to their potential applications in solid-state lasers, 3D waveguides, optical amplifiers, visible displays, and so on [1]. Among
RE
3 +
$\mathrm{RE}^{3+}$ ions, trivalent holmium (
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ) has been considered as a suitable ion for both visible and infrared emissions due to its unique energy level structure, and hence great efforts have been made on the
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped glass systems [2–14]. Apart from these,
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ion exhibits intense green, weak blue, and red emissions, which are beneficial for the lasers and IR to visible converters; on the other hand, the infrared emissions at 1.2, 1.65, and 2.0 μm emissions are useful for the respective development of O-/U-band amplifiers and eye-safe midinfrared lasers [15]. All these properties depend on phonon energy of the host matrix, which rules multiphonon relaxation of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions. Hence, there is a need of rigorous search for suitable host matrix for
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions to obtain high quantum efficiency of emission.

Fluoride glasses are proved to be good hosts for
RE
3 +
$\mathrm{RE}^{3+}$ ions as they exhibit low phonon energies that lead to efficient luminescence of
RE
3 +
$\mathrm{RE}^{3+}$ ions. However, poor chemical durability and thermal stability limit the application of these nonoxide glasses. Compared with nonoxide glasses, oxide glasses are superior for practical applications due to their high thermal stability and chemical durability. Further, these glasses are attractive hosts as they exhibit excellent optical linearity, highly transparent over large spectral ranges and producible with high optical quality in bulk, fiber, and 3D waveguide form. Among different oxide glass hosts, phosphate-based multicomponent glasses are of great interest due to their unique characteristics that include high transparency, low melting points, high thermal stability, low refractive index, and low dispersion. These properties make the phosphate glasses as an attractive materials for device fabrication.

In this direction, it is interesting to study the spectroscopic properties of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions in K–Sr–Al phosphate glasses using the Judd–Ofelt (JO) theory [16, 17]. The luminescence properties such as effective bandwidths, stimulated emission cross-sections, and branching ratios have been determined for different excited states of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ion and discussed with reported systems.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para:
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped phosphate glasses of chemical composition (
( 59 − x / 2 )
P 2
O 5
– 17
K 2
O – ( 15 − x / 2 ) SrO – 9
Al 2
O 3
− x
Ho 2
O 3
$(59-x/2)\mathrm{P}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{5}\mbox{--} 17 \mathrm{K}_{2}\mathrm{O}\mbox{--}(15-x/2)\mathrm{SrO}\mbox{--}9\mathrm{Al}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}- x\mathrm{Ho}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ , where
x = 0.1
$x = 0.1$ , 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 mol%, labeled as PKSAH01, PKSAH05, PKSAH10, and PKSAH20, respectively) were prepared by conventional melt quenching technique. These glasses were prepared by melting stoichiometric amounts of high-purity
Al
(
PO 3
)
3
$\mathrm{Al}(\mathrm{PO}_{3})_{3}$ ,
Sr
(
PO 3
)
2
$\mathrm{Sr}(\mathrm{PO}_{3})_{2}$ ,
KPO 3
$\mathrm{KPO}_{3}$ and
Ho 2
O 3
$\mathrm{Ho}_{2}\mathrm{O}_{3}$ chemical constituents in platinum crucible at 1135 °C for 80 min and followed by air quenching onto a preheated brass plate. Then the glasses were annealed at 488 °C for 12 h to remove thermal strains and stress and cooled down to room temperature. The glasses were cut into required dimensions and then polished for optical measurements.

The following physical properties of PKSAH10 glass were measured. The density was measured by Archimedes’ principle using water as an immersion liquid and was found to be 2.74 g/cc. The
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ concentration was estimated as
2.55 ×
10
20
$2.55 \times 10^{20}$ ions/cc. The refractive index was measured by Abbe refractometer at sodium wavelength (589.3 nm) with 1-bromonapthalene
(
C 10
H 7
Br )
$(\mathrm{C}_{10}\mathrm{H}_{7}\mathrm{Br})$ as a contact liquid and was determined to be 1.518. The absorption spectrum was measured using Perkin Elmer Lambda-950 spectrophotometer in the range of 300–2400 nm. The emission and excitation spectra were measured using Jobin Yvon Fluorolog-3 spectrofluorimeter using 450 W Xenon arc lamp as an excitation source.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Differential thermal analysis and Raman measurements have been carried out in order to know the thermal stability and vibrational modes of similar host composition doped with different
RE
3 +
$\mathrm{RE}^{3+}$ ions as reported elsewhere [18, 19]. The absorption spectrum of PKSAH10 glass was measured in the range of 300–2400 nm and is shown in Fig. 1. The spectrum consists of inhomogeneously broadened
4
f 10
$4f^{10}$ –
4
f 10
$4f^{10}$ transitions that originate from the
I 8
5
${}^{5}I_{8}$ ground state to various excited states of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ion. The experimental oscillator strengths (
f exp
$f_{\exp}$ ) have been obtained for observed transitions using the following relation [20]:

${}^{5}I_{7} \to {}^{5}I_{8}$ transitions have greater than 0.5 predicted branching ratios with energy difference greater than 3000 cm−1. This result confirms that the

τ rad
$\tau_{\mathrm{rad}}$ for excited levels of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions in different glasses have been presented in Table 4. As can be seen from Table 4, the
τ rad
$\tau_{\mathrm{rad}}$ is found to be higher for all the levels compared to LKBBG [5], PBG [6], and ZnO–
TeO 2
$\mathrm{TeO}_{2}$ [11] glasses that could be due to the higher covalency of Ho–O bond in the present glass but lower than PKAPbNHo10 and SAZN [7] glasses. Hence,
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped phosphate glasses can be considered as an active medium to achieve laser action.

The excitation spectrum of the PKSAH10 glass was obtained by monitoring the emission at 547 nm and is shown in Fig. 2. The spectrum reveals eight excitation bands centered at 335, 346, 362, 384, 418, 451, 470, and 485 nm, corresponding to the
I 8
5
→ 3
F 4
, 3
L 9
, 3
H 6
, 5

, 5

F 3
5
${}^{5}F_{3}$ transitions, respectively. Among these excitation bands, the peak at 451 nm is sharp and intense, and it has been used to excite the PKSAH glasses and in turn investigate their luminescence properties. The visible emission spectra of PKSAH glasses were measured by exciting at 451 nm and are shown in Fig. 3. The spectrum exhibits three emission bands centered at 492, 547, and 662 nm. The blue emission observed at 492 nm is assigned to the
F 3
5
→ 5
I 8
${}^{5}F_{3} \to {}^{5}I_{8}$ transition. The dominant green emission at 547 nm is attributed to the transition from thermalized
S 2

The gain coefficient
G ( λ , P )
$G(\lambda,P)$ was evaluated by assuming that all the ions are either at the ground
I 8
5
$^{5}I_{8}$ state or at the upper
I 7
5
$^{5}I_{7}$ level through the following formula:
11
G ( λ , P ) = N
[ P
σ e
(
λ p
) − ( 1 − P )

( λ ) ]
,
$$ G(\lambda,P) = N \bigl[ P\sigma_{e}(\lambda_{p}) - (1 - P) \sigma_{a}(\lambda ) \bigr], $$ where
P
$P$ stands for the population of the upper

5

Ho

P
$P$ (
P = 0
$P = 0$ to 1, in steps of 0.2) and is shown in Fig. 6. It displays that a wide tunable range from 1900 to 2100 nm is expected when
P
$P$ is larger than 0.6. As seen from Fig. 6, the gain coefficient increases and the gain band extends toward shorter wavelength region. The peak of the gain rate exhibits blue shift with increasing
P
$P$ . This variation is a typical feature of the quasi-three-level laser system. Thus, it is expected that this kind of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ -doped K–Sr–Al phosphate glasses would be an appropriate host material to achieve infrared emission due to higher gain properties.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
Spectroscopic properties of K–Sr–Al phosphate glasses doped with
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions have been investigated. The Judd–Ofelt intensity parameters are determined to be
Ω 2
= 11.39
$\varOmega_{2} = 11.39$ ,
Ω 4
= 3.59
$\varOmega_{4} = 3.59$ , and
Ω 6
= 2.92
$\varOmega_{6} = 2.92$
( ×
10
− 20
cm 2
)
$(\times10^{-20}~\mathrm{cm}^{2})$ , indicating that the present glasses exhibit higher covalency between Ho–O bond and asymmetry around
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ions. The radiative properties for various excited states of
Ho
3 +
$\mathrm{Ho}^{3+}$ ion have been analyzed using the Judd–Ofelt theory and predicted lifetime was found to be 296 μs for
S 2
5
${}^{5}S_{2}$ level. An efficient green emission ascribed to
S 2
5
( 5
F 4
)
→ 5
I 8
${}^{5}S_{2} ( {}^{5}F_{4} ) \to {}^{5}I_{8}$ transition was observed under 451 nm excitation with stimulated emission cross-section of
1.53 ×
10
− 20
$1.53 \times 10^{-20}$ cm2. The emission cross-section at 2.05 μm is estimated using the McCumber theory and was found to be
9.3 ×
10
− 2 1
$9.3 \times 10^{-2 1}$ cm2, which is larger than the values
5.5 ×
10
− 2 1
$5.5 \times 10^{-2 1}$ cm2,
4.8 ×
10
− 2 1
$4.8 \times 10^{-2 1}$ cm2, and
4.0 ×
10
− 2 1
$4.0 \times 10^{-2 1}$ cm2 in LKBBG, PBG, and fluorozirconate glasses, respectively. These results indicate that the titled glasses could be useful for the development of visible and infrared lasers.
